channel.title: NPR Topics: World
channel.description: NPR world news, international art and culture, world business and financial markets, world economy, and global trends in health, science and technology. Subscribe to the World Story of the Day podcast and RSS feed.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Trump quiere que petroleras estadounidenses lleguen a Venezuela. Esto es lo que usted debe saber
item.description: El Presidente Donald Trump quiere que más compañías petroleras estadounidenses se incorporen a Venezuela. Pero existen razones económicas e históricas que podrían dificultar su acceso.
item.content:encoded:
El Presidente Donald Trump quiere que más compañías petroleras estadounidenses se incorporen a Venezuela. Pero existen razones económicas e históricas que podrían dificultar su acceso.

(Image credit: Matias Delacroix)
item.dc:creator: Julia Simon

item.title: How are Greenlanders responding to Trump's threats to acquire the territory?
item.description: NPR's Juana Summers speaks to Naaja Nathanielsen, a government minister in Greenland, about President Trump's latest threats to buy or acquire the territory, and how Greenlanders are responding.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Juana Summers speaks to Naaja Nathanielsen, a government minister in Greenland, about President Trump's latest threats to buy or acquire the territory, and how Greenlanders are responding.
item.dc:creator: Matt Ozug

item.title: Southern Yemen separatist group says it will dissolve after its head fled to the UAE
item.description: Yemen's Southern Transitional Council and its institutions will be dismantled after weeks of unrest in southern areas and a day after its leader fled to the United Arab Emirates.
item.content:encoded:
Yemen's Southern Transitional Council and its institutions will be dismantled after weeks of unrest in southern areas and a day after its leader fled to the United Arab Emirates.

(Image credit: AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Venezuela releases imprisoned opposition figures, which Trump says U.S. requested
item.description: Venezuela released a number of imprisoned high-profile opposition figures, activists and journalists, in what the government described as a gesture to "seek peace".
item.content:encoded:
Venezuela released a number of imprisoned high-profile opposition figures, activists and journalists, in what the government described as a gesture to "seek peace".

(Image credit: Matias Delacroix)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Many Americans say the U.S. is not a moral leader but want it to be: NPR/Ipsos poll
item.description: Commissioned by NPR in partnership with Ipsos, the poll also highlights sharp partisan divides on key foreign policy issues.
item.content:encoded:
Commissioned by NPR in partnership with Ipsos, the poll also highlights sharp partisan divides on key foreign policy issues.

(Image credit: Samuel Corum)
item.dc:creator: Vincent Ni

item.title: Trump to meet with U.S. oil executives for help reviving Venezuela's oil industry
item.description: President Trump wants U.S. oil companies to help revitalize Venezuela's struggling oil industry. But with oil prices low and the political future uncertain, oil companies may be reluctant to gamble.
item.content:encoded: President Trump wants U.S. oil companies to help revitalize Venezuela's struggling oil industry. But with oil prices low and the political future uncertain, oil companies may be reluctant to gamble.
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: Trump says the U.S. could be in Venezuela for 'years.' What that could look like
item.description: President Trump has said the U.S. may be "running" Venezuela for years, raising questions about the administration's plans for the country and how long they might take.
item.content:encoded: President Trump has said the U.S. may be "running" Venezuela for years, raising questions about the administration's plans for the country and how long they might take.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Kurtzleben

item.title: A long U.S. stay in Venezuela? What past interventions reveal
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Washington Post columnist David Ignatius about what the U.S. staying in Venezuela for years might look like and the history of U.S. involvement in other countries.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Washington Post columnist David Ignatius about what the U.S. staying in Venezuela for years might look like and the history of U.S. involvement in other countries.
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep

item.title: Russia uses its new Oreshnik missile in a big attack on Ukraine and a warning to West
item.description: For only the second time, Russia used a new ballistic missile that it says flies at 10 times the speed of sound and is unstoppable by air defenses.
item.content:encoded:
For only the second time, Russia used a new ballistic missile that it says flies at 10 times the speed of sound and is unstoppable by air defenses.

(Image credit: Efrem Lukatsky)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Iran's supreme leader says protesters are 'ruining their own streets' to please Trump
item.description: Iran's supreme leader signaled Friday that security forces would crack down on protesters after they screamed from windows and marched through the streets overnight, directly challenging U.S. President Trump's pledge to support those peacefully demonstrating.
item.content:encoded:
Iran's supreme leader signaled Friday that security forces would crack down on protesters after they screamed from windows and marched through the streets overnight, directly challenging U.S. President Trump's pledge to support those peacefully demonstrating.

(Image credit: AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
